item.title: Ryan add a quote by Haruki Murakami
item.description: "For both of us, it had simply been too enormous an experience. We shared it by <i>not talking about it</i>. Does this make any sense?" -- Haruki Murakami

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Haruki Murakami
item.description: "This person, this self, this me, finally, was made somewhere else. Everything had come from somewhere else, and it would all go somewhere else. I was nothing but a pathway for the person known as me." -- Haruki Murakami

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Haruki Murakami
item.description: "If, through some kind of reincarnation, it were possible to be reborn as Ushikawa's clothing, with a guarantee of rare glory in the <i>next</i> rebirth, I would still not want to do it." -- Haruki Murakami

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Cormac McCarthy
item.description: "Then they set out along the blacktop in the gunmetal light, shuffling through the ash, each the other's world entire." -- Cormac McCarthy

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Cormac McCarthy
item.description: "People were always getting ready for tomorrow. I didn't believe in that. Tomorrow wasn't getting ready for them. It didn't even know they were there." -- Cormac McCarthy

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Cormac McCarthy
item.description: "Perhaps in the world's destruction it would be possible at last to see how it was made. Oceans, mountains. The ponderous counterspectacle of things ceasing to be. The sweeping waste, hydroptic and coldly secular. The silence." -- Cormac McCarthy

item.title: Ryan add a quote by W.S. Merwin
item.description: "I had hardly begun to read I asked how can you ever be sure that what you write is really any good at all and he said you can't you can't you can never be sure you die without knowing whether anything you wrote was any good if you have to be sure don't write" -- W.S. Merwin

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Italo Calvino
item.description: "In the Ondariva gardens the branches spread out like the tentacles of extraordinary animals, and the plants on the ground opened up stars of fretted leaves like the green skins of reptiles, and waved feathery yellow bamboos with a rustle like paper." -- Italo Calvino

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Anthony Bourdain
item.description: "Vegetarians, and their Hezbollah-like splinter faction, the vegans ... are the enemy of everything good and decent in the human spirit." -- Anthony Bourdain

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Bill Buford
item.description: "All this intelligent and careful work revealed a man of great forethought. Yet you could see in Mr. Wicks's eyes--as he stood in the shade of the terminal awning, all that tweed and education waving to us, as one by one each bus pulled out for the noisy drive into the city--that he had failed." -- Bill Buford

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Bill Buford
item.description: "This was a mouth that had suffered many slings and arrows along with the occasional thrashing and several hundredweight of tobacco and Cadbury's milk chocolate. This was a mouth through which a great deal of life had passed at, it would appear, an uncompromising speed." -- Bill Buford

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Michael Pollan
item.description: "... the way we eat represents our most profound engagement with the natural world. Daily, our eating turns nature into culture, transforming the body of the world into our bodies and minds." -- Michael Pollan

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Bill Buford
item.description: "The crowd is not us. It never is." -- Bill Buford

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Michael Pollan
item.description: "A charge often levied against organic agriculture is that it is more philosophy than science. There's some truth to this indictment, if that it what it is, though why organic farmers should feel defensive about it is itself a mystery, a relic, perhaps, of our fetishism of science as the only credible tool with which to approach nature. ... The peasant rice farmer who introduces ducks and fish to his paddy may not understand all the symbiotic relationships he's put in play--that the ducks and fishes are feeding nitrogen to the rice and at the same time eating the pests. But the high yields of food from this ingenious polyculture are his to harvest even so." -- Michael Pollan

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Jack Kerouac
item.description: "As we rode in the bus in the weird phosphorescent void of the Lincoln Tunnel we leaned on each other with fingers waving and yelled and talked excitedly, and I was beginning to get the bug like Dean." -- Jack Kerouac

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Junot Díaz
item.description: "To exhaustion and beyond they prayed, to that glittering place where the flesh dies and is born again, where all is agony, and finally, just as La Inca was feeling her spirit begin to loose itself from its earthly pinions, just as the circle began to dissolve--" -- Junot Díaz

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Junot Díaz
item.description: "Wondering aloud, If we were orcs, wouldn't we, at a racial level, <i>imagine</i> ourselves to look like elves?" -- Junot Díaz

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Junot Díaz
item.description: "Their flashlight newly activated, they walked him into the cane--never had he heard anything so loud and alien, the susurration, the crackling, the flashes of motion underfoot (snake? mongoose?), overhead even the stars, all of them gathered in vainglorious congress." -- Junot Díaz

item.title: Ryan add a quote by John Hodgman
item.description: "We all know he kept a bowl of live frogs by his resting slab in the Oval Office that he would snack on during meetings." -- John Hodgman

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Barbara W. Tuchman
item.description: "The muffled tongue of Big Ben tolled nine by the clock as the cortege left the palace, but on history's clock it was sunset, and the sun of the old world was setting in a dying blaze of splendor never to be seen again." -- Barbara W. Tuchman

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Tad Williams
item.description: "... Humans turn the places they live into great crowded piles of mud and stone, like the nests termites build--but what happens when in all the world there are only termite hills left but no bush?" -- Tad Williams

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Tad Williams
item.description: "The world was all mud and wire. The war in the heavens was only a faint imitation of the horror men had learned to make." -- Tad Williams

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Cory Doctorow
item.description: "We were dancing, lost in the godbeat and the thrash and the screaming--TAKE IT BACK! TAKE IT BACK!" -- Cory Doctorow

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Bryan Christy
item.description: "A squiggle, they are believed to be the first animal ever drawn." -- Bryan Christy

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Lauren Groff
item.description: "As I touched the beast I remembered how, even on that long-ago night, I could feel a tremendous thing moving in the depths below me, something vast and white and singing." -- Lauren Groff

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Lauren Groff
item.description: "And as I walked, I believed myself to be an Adam setting foot in a new Eden, sinless and wild-eyed, my sinews still stiff with creation." -- Lauren Groff

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Richard Fortey
item.description: "But, for now, I retreated back down the little hidden staircase into the familiar world of the basement of the Natural History Museum, and to the embrace of the trilobites." -- Richard Fortey

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Clay Shirky
item.description: "We’re collectively living through 1500, when it’s easier to see what’s broken than what will replace it." -- Clay Shirky

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Carrie Fisher
item.description: "The only one who didn't know was George Lucas. We kept it from him, because we wanted to see what his face looked like when it changed expression--and he fooled us even then. He got Industrial Light and Magic to change his facial expressions for him and THX sound to make the noise of a face-changing expression." -- Carrie Fisher

item.title: Ryan add a quote by Sam Llewellyn
item.description: "There were no larks anymore. There was only the setting sun spreading blood up the sky and the yowl of hounds on a breast-high scent." -- Sam Llewellyn
